Presenting Problem / Chief Complaint: The patient expresses a desire to further their psychology studies, motivated by a need for personal growth and to be a better role model for their children.
History of Present Illness (HPI): The patient feels overwhelmed with parenting but is gradually improving. They are focusing on positives and celebrating small victories, although they still face challenges with their mother regarding parenting decisions.
Psychosocial History: The patient has been busy with work and family, managing stress through family activities like watching movies.
Physiological Observations: The patient reports no signs of physiological issues and has been engaging in family activities to unwind.
Progress Evaluation: The patient shows signs of improvement in managing parenting stress and is motivated to pursue further education.
Therapeutic Interventions: The patient is encouraged to set boundaries with their mother and celebrate small successes in parenting. They are also exploring strategies to manage time effectively for studying.
Next Steps: The patient plans to dedicate three to four hours a week to studying and is considering creating a schedule to stay organized.
